summary: This is an email from a prosecutor to counsel for JPMorgan Chase regarding the status of the bank's response to a subpoena in the Epstein case. It details what documents JPMorgan is ready to produce (onboarding docs, KYC forms, account statements for 66 accounts, wire data) and what is not being produced (loan files, safe deposit records, email correspondence). It also mentions a separate subpoena from the Attorney General of the US Virgin Islands.

persons.name: Assistant U.S. Attorney
persons.context: The author of the email, communicating with JPMorgan Chase's counsel about the status of the bank's subpoena response in the Epstein investigation.

events.title: Status Update on JPMorgan Subpoena
events.description: An Assistant U.S. Attorney emails JPMorgan Chase's counsel to discuss the status of the bank's response to a subpoena, detailing what documents are ready for production and what is being withheld.

keyFacts: JPMorgan Chase was ready to produce documents related to 66 accounts associated with Jeffrey Epstein and Ghislaine Maxwell, including onboarding docs, KYC forms, account statements, and wire data.
The bank did not find loan files or safe deposit records, and cashier's checks were difficult to obtain.
The prosecutors agreed to hold in abeyance the requirement to produce email and telephonic communications requested in the subpoena, but noted they may seek them in the future.
A separate subpoena had been received by JPMorgan from the Attorney General of the U.S. Virgin Islands (AG USVI).

The prosecutor expressed a general preference that entities not share the exact same documents produced for this investigation with other parties, and had specific concerns about the production of the subpoena itself to others.
